comment.author: 42400804@N05
comment._content: my mother grew up in Brisbane.  I was baptised there in 1949.  but I've never been there as an adult. if I'd known it was so beautiful maybe I'd have made the effort...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: This stretch of the Brisbane River is known as Petrie Bight. In the 19th and earlier 20th centuries it was one of Brisbane's main wharf precincts. The Customs House is one of colonial Brisbane's few surviving public buildings. By some miracle it escaped demolition, and in the 1990s was taken over and restored by the University of Queensland who now use it as a venue for seminars, cultural activities, etc. Apart from the Customs House, and the river of course, little of this panorama remains.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Thanks Quasymody, our records have been updated.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Note there's no Moreton Bay fig tree beside the Customs House in this pic...hopefully this will help us to date the pic. In the ANMM pic...towards the rhs we see the National Hotel (architect Richard Gailey), built, ca. 1889 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article84757074 ; the fancy pants mansard roof and turrets were later removed when an additional story was added...still trying to establish when...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I wish the photographer had used T-Max...then we could probably read the name of the paddle steamer... ! Doesn't matter...looks as if it's the Boko...arrived in Brisbane 1879 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1368760 ...converted to a lighter 1917...read all about it here www.tynetugs.co.uk/boko1877.html ; for part of its life it was also put to use as a pleasure cruise vessel...tug during the week, bay trips on public holidays...I've also seen one newspaper item which indicates that at one point it was used as a regatta flagship...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
L. Marks & Co had a large furniture warehouse in Queen St, opposite the Customs House...they appear to have started trading there in late 1903...I'm not yet sure this is their building we see above...work in progress

I suspect that cupola we see to the left of St Paul's spire might have been the Central Fire Station, which was located at the corner of Ann & Wharf Sts...it had a cupola which is quite similar to this (the link to the pic at the SLQ keeps dropping out) ...I can't find anything on-line which gives a definite construction date...one digitised newspaper item suggests ca. 1906-1907...but I'm not anywhere near 100% convinced it is the Central Fire Station.

My fig tree theory says this pic was taken in ca. 1900 at the latest...but some of the buildings on view tend to suggest the pic was taken maybe as late as 1907...so I'm basically clueless re a possible date...we need an arborist to give us some info on the growth rate of Moreton Bay fig trees.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Thanks Quasymody, this image has some challenges. The paddlesteamer is a great find - thanks for the ID! We have put your research into our database for this image :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
